pullRequest.body:
Add in a number of useful theorems (reflexivity, closure under multiplication) and lemmas about when the PresentedMonoid.rel holds as an API for users

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [053575fa32](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19062/commits/053575fa329a7ee5d11c5713d9083854120e5c5a)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ append_left`
`+ append_right`
`+ mul_rel_left`
`+ mul_rel_right`
`+ of_rel`
`+ of_rel_symm`
`+ one_step`
`+ one_step_symm`
`+ rel_left`
`+ rel_right`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

It is not clear (to me) why this definition is needed. We have `ConGen.Rel` already, this redefines it in a special case, duplicates some API and adds more API which could just be added to ConGen.Rel already couldn't it? For example `append_left` (which could be called `mul_congr_left`) could just be a general lemma about `ConGen.Rel` right?

> It is not clear (to me) why this definition is needed. We have `ConGen.Rel` already, this redefines it in a special case, duplicates some API and adds more API which could just be added to ConGen.Rel already couldn't it? For example `append_left` (which could be called `mul_congr_left`) could just be a general lemma about `ConGen.Rel` right?

I am happy to change it; here is my reasoning:

This hides the fact that presented monoids are implemented as quotients of congruence relations. 

For one, users can simply use the presented monoid interface without worrying about its implementation, and going digging in other files to get what they need. 

Secondly, it is entirely conceivable that presented monoids might be re-implemented in a different way in the future (eventually, I will be PR'ing some things about Semi-Thue systems, defined as the reflexive, transitive, multiplicative (not symmetric!) closure of a relation. Presented monoids are also called Thue systems, and maybe people will think it is better to implement them similarly to Thue systems)

Lastly, I can envision having some iff lemmas; if they are defined only for ConGen, then I would have to unfold PresentedMonoid in order to `rw` with them

(Overall, I thought to add these to PresentedMonoid rather than in Con because of PresentedMonoid's second interpretation as a string re-writing system, so I want to provide good support for that use case --- of which I have made much use in my braid monoid proofs)

Every new definition clogs up the system a bit more (for example we'll need to teach simp how to deal with it). I think it's unlikely we're going to change the definition of presented monoid, and, if we do, we could copy over the API at that time. At the discussion at the triage meeting people seem to be in favour of just adding more API to `ConGen.Rel` rather than merging this new definition. Does this sound OK with you?

Fine by me! I’ll delete the PR this afternoon

On Mon, Feb 10, 2025 at 5:21 AM Kevin Buzzard ***@***.***>
wrote:

> Every new definition clogs up the system a bit more (for example we'll
> need to teach simp how to deal with it). I think it's unlikely we're going
> to change the definition of presented monoid, and, if we do, we could copy
> over the API at that time. At the discussion at the triage meeting people
> seem to be in favour of just adding more API to ConGen.Rel rather than
> merging this new definition. Does this sound OK with you?
>
> —
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/19062#issuecomment-2647548743>,
> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/A5MCGATXTJNQA4BC4REFSE32PB4RTAVCNFSM6AAAAABR2DIHGKVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMZDMNBXGU2DQNZUGM>
> .
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID:
> ***@***.***>
>

> Can this be closed?

I think it makes more sense for me to keep this PR open and simply move the lemmas into the Congruence file, which I'll do right now :)

These names look strange (to me) and also they're in a funny place in the file: they seem harder than `append_left`, `mul_rel_right` etc (in fact they're easy corollaries of them, probably the proofs could be made shorter using them?)

pullRequest.title: feat(Algebra/PresentedMonoid/Basic) : facts about rel
